newsitem.title: USA: The teddy market is rallying.
newsitem.headline: The teddy market is rallying.

text.p: The bear market has arrived and it's growing. Not stocks, but teddy bears, which impart a warm fuzzy feeling especially if you have, say, a $170,000 Steiff original from 1904.
It's not the money that counts, though, for "arctophiles" or "bearologists" whose numbers are dwarfed only by stamp and coin collectors.

"Psychologically, the bear in general is maternally probably the most protective in nature of its young. They tend to project a soulfulness that children as well as adults tend to find," said Ken Yenke, collector and dealer based in Strongsville, Ohio (216-238-5363).
"And I think there is a little girl or boy in all of us," said British collector and connoisseur Pam Hebbs.

At a Christie's London auction in December, 1994, Hebbs successfully bid a record 110,000 British sterling ($169,200) on behalf of toy manufacturer Yoshihiro Sekiguchi for Teddy Girl, a 20-inch Steiff bear made in 1904. German-based Steiff is regarded as the first true teddy bear manufacturer.
Until then, the record holder was "Happy," a 1920s Steiff bear that sold for $74,000 in 1989, Yenke said.

That's a far cry from the turn of the century, when a basic 12-inch high teddy bear cost 25 cents to $1. "That same bear today would cost $100 to $500 per inch," depending on its rarity, quality and condition, Yenke said.

First made in New York in 1903, teddies got their name from a famous Washington Post cartoon of President Theodore (Teddy) Roosevelt refusing to shoot a baby bear tied to a tree even though his Mississippi hunting trip had been fruitless.
Oct. 27, Roosevelt's birthday, is now Teddy Bear Day in several states and is celebrated with conventions and shows.

Originally made for boys, teddies soon became a fixture in nurseries across North America and Europe, helped by the success of A.A. Milne's series of "Winnie-the-Pooh" books in Britain in the 1920s. The decade after World War II was also boomtime for teddies.

But the Bull Era for the bear market began only in the early 1980s, this time spreading to Asia, fuelled by the popular British television series "Brideshead Revisited" that featured a major character with a teddy.

"It was only in mid-1980s that a Steiff bear auctioned for over $1,000," said Yenke. "That was the beginning of the acknowledgment of the teddy bear as a three-dimensional work of art, a soft sculpture."

Early teddies were usually rigid, fully-jointed, hand-sewn models of mohair stuffed with wood shavings. They often had eyes made of glass or precious stones. A wider range of materials is now used, but the pattern and body style still follows the standard set by Steiff's early bears.

While early Steiffs -- especially rare black ones -- are the benchmark, any pre-World War II bear is also valuable and a Steiff that cost $2 in the early 1940s is now worth $2,000. Other desirable pedigrees are Farnell from Britain in the 1920s or Merrythought from England in the 1930s.
Modern celebrities include Muffy Vanderbera and Teddy Van Der Bear, which come with complete lines of "bearaphernalia" -- clothing, jewelry and ornaments -- and which have their own fan clubs.

For unique looks, however, collectors are increasingly snapping up hand-made bears, often autographed on the sole by the artist, for $50 to thousands of dollars each. Artists' bears are the place to start for new collectors because they are quality goods made to last, Yenke advised.

After all, in the bear market, it's the face that launches the blue chips. "The value is almost 100 percent in the face, the look of the bear. Is the bear talking to me? It's a certain attachment or communication that some artistically made bears have," Yenke said.
If the face is good, a few worn spots would not reduce the teddy's value. But a damaged face on a well-kept body will certainly damage its appeal.

The most desirable material is mohair from the Angora goat, which is most like a real animal's fur and may cost up to $300 a yard. "It's easy to clean, resists wear, and is very cuddly. It has a very realistic feel," Yenke said.
For new collectors with limited budgets, artists' bears are the place to start because they are quality goods made to last, Yenke advised.
But even if all you want is friendly company, there is an affordable bear out there as a ballerina, nurse, hiker, drummer or with just a plain sad face that speaks to you.
